content.statement: marfan-001-definition is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Genetic-Connective-Tissue Marfan-Syndrome that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding marfan-001-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of marfan-001-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of marfan-001-definition.

definite_diagnosis: Aortic root Z-score ≥2 AND ectopia lentis
Aortic root Z-score ≥2 AND causal FBN1 mutation
Aortic root Z-score ≥2 AND systemic score ≥7
Ectopia lentis AND causal FBN1 mutation with known aortic involvement

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain

cardiovascular.aortic_root_dilation: Most common and serious - present in 80-90%
cardiovascular.mitral_valve_prolapse: Present in 75%, may cause significant regurgitation
cardiovascular.aortic_dissection: Major cause of death if prophylactic surgery not performed

ocular.ectopia_lentis: Present in 60%, typically superotemporal lens displacement

definition.@value: Autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder due to FBN1 mutation, characterized by aortic root dilation, ectopia lentis, and skeletal features

learning_objectives: Apply Ghent criteria for Marfan diagnosis
Understand the role of FBN1 in aortic pathology
clinical_pearls: Aortic root Z-score ≥2 is the cardiovascular criterion - use Z-scores, not absolute measurements in young patients
25% of cases are de novo mutations - no family history doesn't exclude diagnosis
Beta-blockers and losartan slow aortic root dilation
Life expectancy is near-normal with proper surveillance and timely surgery

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
